headline: 1 Profitable Stock to Consider Right Now and 2 We Avoid
summary: Not all profitable companies are built to last - some rely on outdated models or unsustainable advantages. Just because a business is in the green today doesn’t mean it will thrive tomorrow.

headline: Berkshire Hathaway Inc. News Release
summary: OMAHA, Neb., November 10, 2025--Today, Warren E. Buffett converted 1,800 A shares into 2,700,000 B shares in order to give these B shares to four family foundations: 1,500,000 shares to The Susan Thompson Buffett Foundation and 400,000 shares to each of The Sherwood Foundation, The Howard G. Buffett Foundation and NoVo Foundation. These donations have been delivered today.

content.title: Berkshire Hathaway Inc. News Release
content.summary: OMAHA, Neb., November 10, 2025--Today, Warren E. Buffett converted 1,800 A shares into 2,700,000 B shares in order to give these B shares to four family foundations: 1,500,000 shares to The Susan Thompson Buffett Foundation and 400,000 shares to each of The Sherwood Foundation, The Howard G. Buffett Foundation and NoVo Foundation. These donations have been delivered today.

headline: Tesla shake-up, Warren Buffett to 'go quiet' from Berkshire
summary: Yahoo Finance's John Hyland outlines some stories investors are watching on Monday's Market Minute, including leadership changes with Tesla's (TSLA) Cybertruck and Model Y units, and Berkshire Hathaway (BRK-B, BRK-A) CEO Warren Buffett saying he'll retire quietly. Stay up to date on the latest market action, minute-by-minute, with Yahoo Finance's Market Minute.

headline: Warren Buffett will no longer write annual letter, speak at Berkshire Hathaway shareholder meeting
summary: Investing legend Warren Buffett said Monday that he would no longer write an annual letter to Berkshire Hathaway shareholders and would not speak at the company's annual meeting.

headline: Takeaways From Warren Buffett’s Latest Shareholder Letter
summary: Warren Buffett, the 95-year-old chairman and CEO of Berkshire Hathaway, said that he will continue writing his Thanksgiving letter to his children and shareholders each year, though he will no longer be writing Berkshire's annual report once Greg Abel takes over as chief executive at yearend.  In his wide-ranging letter released Monday, Buffett spun the anecdotes and business and life lessons he is known for, while also disclosing some new plans about his giving and how he'll manage his share ownership.  “My children are already 100% behind Greg as are the Berkshire directors.”

content.title: Takeaways From Warren Buffett’s Latest Shareholder Letter
content.summary: Warren Buffett, the 95-year-old chairman and CEO of Berkshire Hathaway, said that he will continue writing his Thanksgiving letter to his children and shareholders each year, though he will no longer be writing Berkshire's annual report once Greg Abel takes over as chief executive at yearend.  In his wide-ranging letter released Monday, Buffett spun the anecdotes and business and life lessons he is known for, while also disclosing some new plans about his giving and how he'll manage his share ownership.  “My children are already 100% behind Greg as are the Berkshire directors.”

headline: Berkshire’s Buffett to Keep Class A Stock Until Investors Get Comfort With Successor
summary: Berkshire Hathaway’s    Warren Buffett  wrote that he will keep a “significant amount” of the company’s Class A stock until shareholders get comfortable with his successor as CEO.  “That level of confidence shouldn’t take long,” Buffett wrote Monday in a letter to his three children and shareholders.  “My children are already 100% behind Greg as are the Berkshire directors.”

headline: Berkshire’s Buffett Plans to Keep Class A Shares Until Successor Wins Over Investors
summary: Berkshire Hathaway’s    Warren Buffett  wrote that he will keep a “significant amount” of the company’s Class A stock until his fellow shareholders grow comfortable with his successor as CEO,  Greg Abel.  “That level of confidence shouldn’t take long,” Buffett wrote Monday in a letter to his three children and shareholders.  “My children are already 100% behind Greg as are the Berkshire directors.”

content.title: Berkshire’s Buffett Plans to Keep Class A Shares Until Successor Wins Over Investors
content.summary: Berkshire Hathaway’s    Warren Buffett  wrote that he will keep a “significant amount” of the company’s Class A stock until his fellow shareholders grow comfortable with his successor as CEO,  Greg Abel.  “That level of confidence shouldn’t take long,” Buffett wrote Monday in a letter to his three children and shareholders.  “My children are already 100% behind Greg as are the Berkshire directors.”

headline: Five Takeaways From Buffett’s Thanksgiving Letter
summary: While he will continue writing his Thanksgiving message to his children and shareholders each year, he will no longer be writing Berkshire's annual shareholder letter once Greg Abel takes over as chief executive at year-end.  In his wide-ranging letter released Monday, Buffett spun the anecdotes and business and life lessons he is known for, while also disclosing some new plans about his giving and how he will manage his share ownership.  Buffett on Buffett: He says he generally feels good.

In his wide-ranging letter released Monday, Buffett spun the anecdotes and business and life lessons he is known for, while also disclosing some new plans about his giving and how he will manage his share ownership.  Buffett on Buffett: He says he generally feels good.

headline: Warren Buffett said he's 'going quiet' ahead of Berkshire transition
summary: Berkshire Hathaway (BRK-A, BRK-B) CEO and Chairman Warren Buffett has begun distributing more of his company shares to his children's foundations as the Oracle of Omaha slowly hands over the reins to his successor, Greg Abel. Buffett announced Monday he will no longer be publishing the company's annual letter to shareholders. Yahoo Finance Head of News Myles Udland comes on Market Domination to react to the news as Buffett said that he's "going quiet." To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination.

content.title: Warren Buffett said he's 'going quiet' ahead of Berkshire transition
content.description:
Berkshire Hathaway (BRK-A, BRK-B) CEO and Chairman Warren Buffett has begun distributing more of his company shares to his children's foundations as the Oracle of Omaha slowly hands over the reins to his successor, Greg Abel. Buffett announced Monday he will no longer be publishing the company's annual letter to shareholders.

Yahoo Finance Head of News Myles Udland comes on Market Domination to react to the news as Buffett said that he's "going quiet."

To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination.
content.summary: Berkshire Hathaway (BRK-A, BRK-B) CEO and Chairman Warren Buffett has begun distributing more of his company shares to his children's foundations as the Oracle of Omaha slowly hands over the reins to his successor, Greg Abel. Buffett announced Monday he will no longer be publishing the company's annual letter to shareholders. headline: ‘Going Quiet’: Nine Big Takeaways From Warren Buffett’s Last Letter as CEO
summary: While he will continue writing his Thanksgiving message to his children and shareholders each year, Buffett will no longer be writing Berkshire’s annual shareholder letter once  Greg Abel  takes over as chief executive at the end of this year.  In wide-ranging thoughts released Monday, Buffett spun the anecdotes and business and life lessons he is known for, while also disclosing some new plans about his philanthropic giving and CEO pay.  Buffett on Buffett: He says he generally feels good, though he feels the effects of aging on his balance, sight, hearing and memory.

In wide-ranging thoughts released Monday, Buffett spun the anecdotes and business and life lessons he is known for, while also disclosing some new plans about his philanthropic giving and CEO pay.  Buffett on Buffett: He says he generally feels good, though he feels the effects of aging on his balance, sight, hearing and memory.

headline: Warren Buffett Lauds Berkshire Stock. It Has Little Chance of ‘Devastating Disaster.’
summary: FEATURE  Warren Buffett highlighted Berkshire Hathaway’s defensive characteristics and its above-average business prospects in his Thanksgiving letter to shareholders released on Monday. “In aggregate, Berkshire’s businesses have moderately better-than-average prospects, led by a few non-correlated and sizable gems.
